page.title: 09SURROUNDING HISTORY 2
page.content:
St Kenelm's Well
This is a small stone pump house which was re-built in 1887. A water supply was first taken to Winchcombe Abbey in lead pipes in the thirteenth century. In 1887 the town of Winchcombe was given a water supply from the Well. St Kenelm was the son of the Saxon king Kenulf. He was supposedly murdered by his sister Quendryth when seven years old. His body was brought back to Winchcombe and at each stopping place a spring of water miraculously appeared. During the Middle Ages it was an important place of pilgrimage. Some of the homes in Winchcombe still have water from this well although now most are connected to the Severn-Trent supply. ENOD06200156
